benchmark_details.name: When, Where, and What? A Novel Benchmark for Accident Anticipation and Localization with Large Language Models
benchmark_details.overview: This study introduces a novel benchmark that integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) to enhance predictive capabilities in anticipating and localizing traffic accidents, utilizing innovative mechanisms to identify when and where accidents might occur.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To develop a comprehensive framework for anticipating and localizing vehicle accidents using Large Language Models.

data.source: Empirical validation on the DAD, CCD, and A3D datasets.
data.size: 620 dashcam recordings (DAD dataset) with 1750 video segments
data.annotation: Annotations for object detection bounding boxes, object IDs, object categories, and labels indicating the occurrence of accidents.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated based on prediction results from the model compared to ground truth labels across various datasets.
methodology.interpretation: Higher AP indicates better accuracy in predicting accidents, while mTTA reflects earlier predictions before accidents occur.
methodology.validation: Model performance validated against existing approaches on several benchmark datasets.
